title: Kinematics: Describing Motion
objectives: Understand the fundamental concepts of motion: position, displacement, velocity, speed, and acceleration.
Differentiate between scalar and vector quantities with real-life examples.
Interpret and construct motion graphs: displacement-time, velocity-time, and acceleration-time graphs.
Analyze motion using gradient and area under curves in velocity-time graphs.
Apply the four kinematic equations to solve one-dimensional and two-dimensional motion problems.
Understand free fall motion and the effects of gravity on objects in the absence of air resistance.
Explain relative motion in one and two dimensions.

title: Newton's Laws of Motion
objectives: State and explain Newton’s First, Second, and Third Laws of Motion.
Differentiate between inertia, mass, and weight, and their relationship to force and acceleration.
Identify and draw free-body diagrams for various physical situations.
Solve problems involving balanced and unbalanced forces in both linear and inclined motion.
Explain real-world examples using each of Newton's laws (e.g., seatbelts, rocket launch, walking).
Understand frictional forces, tension, and normal forces and their effects on motion.
Analyze systems with multiple objects connected by strings, pulleys, or acted on by external forces.

title: Work, Energy, and Power
objectives: Define work done by a constant force and calculate work using the dot product.
Understand the concept of kinetic energy and potential energy (gravitational and elastic).
Apply the Work-Energy Theorem to analyze motion in mechanical systems.
Use conservation of mechanical energy to solve problems involving no non-conservative forces.
Identify and quantify the effect of friction and air resistance as non-conservative forces.
Calculate mechanical power and understand its relationship to work and time.
Differentiate between efficiency, ideal and real machines, and solve problems using efficiency formulas.

title: Momentum and Collisions
objectives: Define linear momentum and impulse and understand the impulse-momentum theorem.
Apply the law of conservation of momentum to isolated systems in one and two dimensions.
Differentiate between elastic, inelastic, and perfectly inelastic collisions with examples.
Solve real-world collision problems including those with recoil (e.g., firearms, explosions).
Understand the principles of explosion mechanics and energy dissipation in collisions.
Interpret momentum-time graphs and calculate impulse from them.
Use vector addition and diagramming to solve momentum problems involving angles.

title: Circular Motion and Gravitation
objectives: Understand the concepts of angular displacement, angular velocity, and angular acceleration.
Relate linear motion quantities to angular motion quantities using radius.
Explain the requirement for centripetal force and acceleration in uniform circular motion.
Analyze examples of circular motion in vertical and horizontal planes (e.g., loop-the-loop, car on a track).
Understand Newton’s Law of Universal Gravitation and apply it to planetary motion.
Calculate gravitational force between two masses and describe field strength.
Distinguish between mass and weight in gravitational fields and their variations with altitude.
Explain orbital motion, satellite mechanics, and Kepler’s Laws qualitatively and quantitatively.
